items.title: Book created from a dict discards ordering
items.body:
[Since Python 3.7, dictionaries preserve order](https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.7.html), so I'd expect the following code to pass:

```python
book = pyexcel.Book(
    {
        "Stuff": [["some", "data", "I", "can't", "parse"]],
        "Records": [["record_id"], ["a"], ["b"], ["c"]],
        "Quarters": [
            ["id", "quarter"],
            ["one", "2021Q1"],
            ["two", "2021Q2"],
        ],
    }
)
assert list(book.sheet_names()) == ["Stuff", "Records", "Quarters"]
```

Unfortunately it does not.

```
E       AssertionError: assert ['Quarters', ...rds', 'Stuff'] == ['Stuff', 'Re...', 'Quarters']
E         At index 0 diff: 'Quarters' != 'Stuff'
E         Full diff:
E         - ['Stuff', 'Records', 'Quarters']
E         + ['Quarters', 'Records', 'Stuff']
```

I'd expect `sheet_names` to return the sheet names in the same order as the source dict.

items.title: Transferring styles during conversion from xls to xlsx
items.body:
I convert from xls to xlsx using pyexcel this way

```
 if filename.endswith('.xls'):
    import pyexcel
    _f, _ = filename.split('.')
    pyexcel.save_book_as(file_name=file, dest_file_name=f'{_f}.xlsx')
```

Then I try to get information about the color of the cell

```
def test_excel_file_response(file):
    pc_coordinate = {}
    workbook = load_workbook(filename=file)
    sheet = workbook["RFI"]
    for row_cells in sheet.iter_rows(min_row=4):
        for cell in row_cells:
            if cell.value in paren_category_ and cell.fill.start_color.rgb:
                pc_coordinate[cell.value] = cell.coordinate
                print(cell.value, cell.fill.start_color)
    return pc_coordinate
```

And get Parameters:
`rgb='00000000', indexed=None, auto=None, theme=None, tint=0.0, type='rgb'`

But when I open a file in the editor, I see that the cells are colored. 
Is it the same problem with style transfer as  https://github.com/pyexcel/pyexcel/issues/206  ?

items.title: Merged cell aren't processed properly?
items.body:
For processing an excel file library openpyxl is used, I need to identify the merged cell. To do this, I call the function `merged_cell_ranges`. 

    workbook = load_workbook(filename=file)
    sheet = workbook["RFI"]
    # get the list of first cell of merged cell coordinate
    list_of_first_coordinate_in_merget_cell = [cell.__str__().split(':')[0] for cell in sheet.merged_cell_ranges]
    for range_ in sheet.merged_cell_ranges:
        # get current coordinate from all merget cell and set it as a string
        cell_obj_to_str = (range_.__str__())
        .....

Work fine for **xlsx**. 
In the project, I need to work with two formats - `xls` and xlsx. 
I convert from xls to xlsx  using **pyexcel** this way 

     if filename.endswith('.xls'):
        import pyexcel
        _f, _ = filename.split('.')
        pyexcel.save_book_as(file_name=file, dest_file_name=f'{_f}.xlsx')

Сonverts everything successfully, openpyxl works with the new file without errors, performs requests and returns all the necessary information. The only problem is that a `merged_cell_ranges` call returns an empty result. 
When opened in the excel editor, I can see that all merged cells are in their places. I don't understand why it doesn't give the result. It looks like some information is lost in the conversion process. Maybe there are thoughts ?

items.title: sheet.column is empty
items.body:
I am creating a new, empty sheet like this:

```python
import pyexcel
sheet = pyexcel.get_sheet(colnames=[ "a", "b", "c", "", "d" ], array=[])
```

I was now expecting to be able to insert data like this:

```python
sheet.column["b"] = [ 1, 2, 3 ]
```

but this always throws an index out of range error. Looking at `sheet.column` with `print(list(sheet.column))` reveals the property to be an empty list. Is this the correct behavior? If if is, then how am I supposed to add data to the sheet?

items.title: XLS to BytesIO response stream created on the fly
items.body:
I'm trying to create response stream with XLS file created on the fly, but only first call to save_to_memory is shown in the downloaded file

The result of the following example is XLS file with only one row of data (instead of 4):



```
import io
import pyexcel as pe
from aiohttp import web

async def get(request):
  response = web.StreamResponse(headers={'Content-Disposition': 'inline; filename="myfile.xls"'})
  await response.prepare(request)
  response.content_type = 'multipart/x-mixed-replace;boundary=ffserver'
  data = [1,2,3,4]
  mem = io.BytesIO()
  sheet = pe.Sheet(name='ids', colnames=['id'])

  try:
      for id in data:
         sheet.extend_rows([id])
         mem = sheet.save_to_memory("xls", mem)
         await response.write(mem.read())
  finally:
      await response.write_eof()
```

Is it even possible doing so with this file format? 

Thanks

items.title: xlsx header reordered when there are blank cells
items.body:
Let temp.csv and temp.xlsx contain the following data:

```
+---+---+---+
| a |   | c |
+---+---+---+
| 1 | 2 | 3 |
+---+---+---+
```

Then the csv is loaded correctly:
```
rows = pyexcel.get_records(file_name='temp.csv')
print(rows[0]) # Correct: "OrderedDict([('a', 1), ('', 2), ('c', 3)])"
```
but the xlsx is not:
```
rows = pyexcel.get_records(file_name='temp.xlsx', sheet_name="Sheet1")
print(rows[0]) # Incorrect: "OrderedDict([('a', 1), ('c', 2), ('', 3)])"
```

items.title: Optional test dependency on pyexcel-handsontable
items.body:
The tests state they depend on `pyexcel-handsontable`, but that depends on @pyecharts , has problem https://github.com/pyexcel-renderers/pyexcel-handsontable/issues/5 , but generally is less mature than `pyexcel`.

The test suite should at least skip the relevant tests when `pyexcel-handsontable` is not installed, so that the packagers dont need to get @pyecharts working before they can get @pyexcel packaged with tests passing.

items.title: Empty (but formatted) rows are read for .ods files
items.body:
Given a file like this one

![captura de pantalla de 2019-01-26 18-15-20](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/932124/51790456-dfcb5800-2195-11e9-937b-a2776a8b8a99.png)

If it is saved as .xlsx everything works fine:

```
import pyexcel
data_xlsx = pyexcel.get_array(file_name="excel_formato_mas_alla_de_los_datos.xlsx")
# [[1, 'a', datetime.date(2019, 12, 30)], [2, 'b', datetime.date(2019, 11, 30)]]
```

But when saving the file as .ods, rows 3 and 4 that are empty of content but have a border, are retrieved with null values:

```
data_ods = pyexcel.get_array(file_name="excel_formato_mas_alla_de_los_datos.ods")
# [[1, 'a', datetime.date(2019, 12, 30)], [2, 'b', datetime.date(2019, 11, 30)], ['', '', ''], ['', '', '']]
```
It's curious that only happens with the rows. The columns D, E also are empty but with border and are not added to the pyexcel array.

[excel_formato_mas_alla_de_los_datos.xlsx](https://github.com/pyexcel/pyexcel/files/2799263/excel_formato_mas_alla_de_los_datos.xlsx)

It is happening to me with `pyexcel-ods` and `pyexcel-ods3`

```
pyexcel             0.5.10     
pyexcel-io         0.5.11     
pyexcel-ods      0.5.4      
pyexcel-xls       0.5.8      
pyexcel-xlsx      0.5.6

pyexcel-ezodf    0.3.4
pyexcel-ods3     0.5.3
```

items.title: Dates export to ods are 'styled' as numbers
items.body:
I'm not sure, if this issue belongs to this repo, or even if it is in the scope of this library, but at least, write it can save some time to others.

When a "date type" is saved to xlsx or ods it is correctly retrieved again by code. But when opening the files with libreoffice, the xlsx file have styled (correctly the date as a date), but the ods file have styled it (incorrectly) as a number.

A code sample to reproduce the issue:

```python
import pyexcel
import datetime

data = [[1, datetime.date(2019, 12, 30)], [2, datetime.date(2019, 11, 30)]]
pyexcel.save_as(array=data, dest_file_name="/tmp/example.xlsx")
pyexcel.save_as(array=data, dest_file_name="/tmp/example.ods")
data_xlsx = pyexcel.get_array(file_name="/tmp/example.xlsx")
# [[1, datetime.date(2019, 12, 30)], [2, datetime.date(2019, 11, 30)]]

data_ods = pyexcel.get_array(file_name="/tmp/example.ods")
# [[1, datetime.date(2019, 12, 30)], [2, datetime.date(2019, 11, 30)]]
```
![captura de pantalla de 2019-01-25 20-55-44](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/932124/51769355-26ac4580-20e3-11e9-9f3e-3dd4784a5313.png)
![captura de pantalla de 2019-01-25 20-56-03](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/932124/51769367-29a73600-20e3-11e9-9838-2e828975abe0.png)

```
$ pip list | grep pyexcel
pyexcel              0.5.10     
pyexcel-io           0.5.11     
pyexcel-ods          0.5.4      
pyexcel-xls          0.5.8      
pyexcel-xlsx         0.5.6
```

I also make a test with `pyexcel-ods3` and the result is better.

![captura de pantalla de 2019-01-25 20-59-52](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/932124/51769540-a6d2ab00-20e3-11e9-9343-8193830cb151.png)

items.title: I can parse some XLSX files but not others. Why is that?
items.body:
Hello!

Myself and two colleagues are trying to parse XLSX files in Python code after retrieving the XLSX file from an e-mail inbox as a message attachment.

Here's a snippet of that code:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/334971/49833171-b5991480-fd66-11e8-9201-412489f6c594.png)

The line

`schedule = pyexcel.get_array(file_stream=StringIO(content), file_type='xlsx')`

works for two of the XLSX files in the targeted inbox. But, for all of the XLSX file attachments in the box, that line throws the following exception:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/334971/49833353-3c4df180-fd67-11e8-8bff-cf35eb80691a.png)

I don't know how to find a significant difference between the XLSX files in question that can be parsed, and those that can be parsed.

The best clue that I have thus far is that if one of my colleagues modifies one the parse-able XLSX files in his desktop version of Excel 2016, and then submits that modified file to the inbox, then we find that the modified file becomes an attachment that causes the script to fail with a BadZipFile exception.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/334971/49833834-b6cb4100-fd68-11e8-923f-83903157f21b.png)

I'll attach several of the sample files.

The ones that can be parsed (by the script in its current form) are:

- ScheduleData 2018-11-04 to 2018-11-10.xlsx
- ScheduleData 2018-11-11 to 2018-11-17.xlsx

The ones that cannot be parsed are:

- ScheduleData 2018-12-02 to 2018-12-08.xlsx
- ScheduleData 2018-12-16 to 2018-12-22.xlsx
- ScheduleData 2018-12-23 to 2018-12-29.xlsx
- SOC Schedule.xlsx

I welcome any input on how I can get the script to parse both the former and the latter set of XLSX files.

Thank you,

[ScheduleData 2018-11-04 to 2018-11-10.xlsx](https://github.com/pyexcel/pyexcel/files/2669667/ScheduleData.2018-11-04.to.2018-11-10.xlsx)
[ScheduleData 2018-11-11 to 2018-11-17.xlsx](https://github.com/pyexcel/pyexcel/files/2669669/ScheduleData.2018-11-11.to.2018-11-17.xlsx)

https://github.com/pyexcel/pyexcel/blob/78a8dc737a0b65499f9e10ffe2696425a2c439db/setup.py#L51

https://github.com/pyexcel/pyexcel/commit/f86dbf9cd11e5db4360a91e995b2013d751e9858#diff-b4ef698db8ca845e5845c4618278f29a

by @chfw 


https://github.com/pyexcel/pyexcel-io/blob/d2e1e8ad9911d352211c50570949b81227120a9f/requirements.txt#L2

https://github.com/pyexcel/pyexcel-io/blob/317e170118bed0b3db7d4ce97c05e65e7d70f773/setup.py#L50

Hey,
So working with files ending with ``.txt`` that are actually ``.csv`` files.
This is in fact the standard in [ Example GTFS Feed ](https://developers.google.com/transit/gtfs/examples/gtfs-feed) which are used by google and governments.

So I need a way to read a file ending in ``.txt`` as a ``.csv``.

I see here in the code that there is a use of ``file_type``, but it would not work if there is a ``file_name`` already defined. Is this a bug or covering a use-case I don't know?
Can I PR something that uses ``force_file_type`` or something like that?
```python
class FileSourceInfo(SourceInfo):
    """Plugin description for a file source"""
    def is_my_business(self, action, **keywords):
        status = SourceInfo.is_my_business(self, action, **keywords)
        if status:
            file_name = keywords.get("file_name", None)
            if file_name:
                if is_string(type(file_name)):
                    file_type = find_file_type_from_file_name(file_name,
                                                              action)
                else:
                    raise IOError("Wrong file name")
            else:
                file_type = keywords.get("file_type")

            status = self.can_i_handle(action, file_type)
        return status
```

items.title: auto_detect_float=True causes all string variations of "nan" to be treated as a NaN entity instead of a string
items.body:
When `auto_detect_float` is set to `True`, any cell with a string value of `nan`, `NaN`, `naN`, etc. will be converted to the `NaN` entity instead of being treated as a string. Possible fixes:

* Only do this if the field actually contains the string `NaN`, with this exact case
* Add an option to treat all variations of `nan` as a string instead of converting it to the `NaN` entity
* Perhaps both of the above

items.title: Excel for Mac Date Offset
items.body:
Hello, first of all, thanks for this great tool.

I'm facing an issue with date formatting: I have some cells containing '6-15', which was intended to represent an integer range, but Excel converts it to date, and when I read the file I get a datetime. This wouldn't be a problem if the datetime I got was correct, but instead of getting `2015-06-01` I'm getting `2011-05-11`.

For what I've seen, Excel stores dates as an integer with the difference in days from `1900-01-01`, but in older versions of Excel for Mac, the 'zero' date is `1904-01-01`, hence the wrong date.

The sheets I'm trying to import can't be modified, so I'm guessing if there's a way to force the reference date for reading, or to get the reference used in the book so I can correct the date after parsing it.

BTW, I think this is exactly the same problem as #54 . I've tested it in my computer, switching from one reference date to another, and the dates match.

items.title: How to order sheets alphabetically using pyexcel? Is this the best way to do so?
items.body:
Hi there, 

I am writing a guide to document some of the more common commands I use with pyexcel.

For ordering sheets alphabetically I wrote this using some clues from documentation:

```
def order_sheets_alphabetically(
    file_path,
    dest_file_path,
    reverse=False
):
    book = pyexcel.get_book(file_name=file_path)
    sheet_names = book.sheet_names()
    sheet_names.sort(reverse=reverse)
    data = OrderedDict()
    for sheet_name in sheet_names:
        data.update({sheet_name: book[sheet_name]})
    return pyexcel.save_book_as(
        bookdict=data, dest_file_name=dest_file_path)
```

Is this the best way of doing so?

items.title: cell_value (matrix.py) function is slow in python2
items.body:
Line 83 in matrix.py 
`if row in self.row_range() and column in self.column_range():`
is not optimal when using python2. Membership test in xrange is very slow when the member value increases. For example try running 
`100000000 in xrange(1000000000)` vs `1 in xrange(1000000000)`

It would be faster to use 
`if row < self.number_of_rows() and column < self.number_of_columns():`

items.title: AttributeError: module 'pyexcel' has no attribute '<module function>'
items.body:
The missing module function could be any one from pyexcel.core:

1. save_as, #89, https://github.com/pyexcel/django-excel/issues/37
2. get_book_dict, #87 

They are identified to be pyexcel 0.5.x and pyexcel-io 0.4.x specific issues.

# Workaround

here is the [workaround](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44658825/how-can-i-get-a-dictionary-from-the-contents-of-a-xlsx-file/44659573#44659573):

    from pyexcel.core import 'module function'

# Potential fix

The current known cure is:

uninstall pyexcel and pyexcel-io until no copies of them found in your python environment. Then install pyexcel and pyexcel-io. 

# More investigation

My problem is that I could not reproduce it in my environment. If you have time to help investigate it, please run this file(trace-pyexcel.py):

    import logging
    import logging.config
    logging.basicConfig(format='%(asctime)s - %(name)s - %(levelname)s - %(message)s',
        level=logging.DEBUG)

    import pyexcel as p
    p.get_book_dict() # or p.save_as()

Here the command line options:

     trace-pyexcel.py > trace_log.txt 2>&1

And please share with me the trace_log.txt for further analysis.

Here is the [OK log](https://github.com/pyexcel/pyexcel/files/1089938/trace_log.txt). But I am after the NOK log.

items.title: pyinstaller packaging: pyexcel.exceptions.UnknownParameters file_name
items.body:
I run Python 3.5.3 (64 bit) on Windows 7 after making exe with pyinstaller 
My script stops working (file and path are checked to be correct), but I got that exception. 
pyexcel.exceptions.UnknownParameters: Please check if there were typos in function parameters: {'file_name': 'C:\\py\\input_data.xls'}. Otherwise unrecognized parameters were given.

Here is function call 
filename = r'C:\py\input_data.xls'
if os.path.exists(filename):
	sheet = pyexcel.get_sheet(file_name=filename)

items.title: AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'get_book_dict'
items.body:
I followed the [docs](https://pyexcel.readthedocs.io/en/latest/tutorial_data_conversion.html#how-to-obtain-a-dictionary-from-a-multiple-sheet-book) and tried to run the code below:
`>>> import pyexcel`
`>>> from pyexcel._compact import OrderedDict`
`>>> my_dict = pyexcel.get_book_dict(file_name="example_series.xls", name_columns_by_row=0)`
`>>> isinstance(my_dict, OrderedDict)`

But it raise the error. But when i try
`from pyexcel.core import *` function `get_book_dict` works. Any help why this issue is coming. If docs are not updated then update it or assign me the issue i will do it.

items.title: file handle not closed
items.body:
The signature functions should have handle file handle explicitly. Here are the behaviour expected:

get_*, save_* functions should close file handle immediately and explicitly.
 iget_*, isave_* should give the file handle 

https://github.com/pyexcel/pyexcel-xlsx/issues/14

items.title: Parsing ODS file: Missing text when there are double/multiple whitespaces in cell
items.body:
Package version:

> Flask-Excel (0.0.5)
> pyexcel (0.4.5)
> pyexcel-io (0.3.3)
> pyexcel-ods (0.3.2)
> pyexcel-webio (0.0.11)
> pyexcel-xls (0.3.1)


I'm using `flask-excel`/`pyexcel` to parse ODS files sent by my users. Recently, I have encountered an ODS file that got parsed improperly by `pyexcel`.  The basic structure of the file is as below:

| id              | name           | 
| --- | --- |
| PRODUCT_ID | PRODUCT NAME  PMP |

The file is attached:
[Product1.ods.zip](https://github.com/pyexcel/pyexcel/files/972829/Product1.ods.zip)

There are double white spaces in between `PRODUCT NAME` and `PMP`. The `pyexcel`'s `get_records` returns only `PMP` for value in the `name` column instead of `PRODUCT NAME  PMP`. 

Note: Github automatically removes double white spaces when I tried to type double white spaces.
